III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
1

(a) Routine and emergency medical, dental, and behavioral health
care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In 05/2025, youth stated having an intent and plan to commit
suicide. A staff member was told about these concerns and
informed that the youth needed to be taken to the hospital that
day. The staff member agreed but youth was never taken to the
hospital. Instead, the staff’s nurse practitioner (NP) came in to
assess the situation. On 06/06/2025, youth attempted the plan by
tying sweatshirt sleeves around neck. Once found, youth was sent
back to the facility and not to the hospital. The NP created a safety
plan and changed youth’s medications. The facility supervisor was
questioned why youth had not been taken to the hospital yet. The
supervisor stated they tried calling the suicide hotline the day
before but no one answered, and it said to call back the next day.
A welfare check was completed on 06/14/2025 and youth was
sent to the hospital and was inpatient from 06/14/2025 to
6/21/2025 due to suicidal ideation. Youth returned to the facility
with increased mental health visits twice a week.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was interviewed on 07/24/2025 by phone.
Complainant did not have additional information.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/24/2025 at Girlstown. Youth A
stated she did not have current thoughts of self-harm. Youth A
was asked to explain what occurred when she had thoughts of
self-harm at Girlstown. Youth A stated she met with the Clinical
Coordinator and developed a safety plan to remind her of coping
strategies and who she can talk with. Youth A stated she feels
comfortable talking with Clinical Coordinator, Case Manager, and
her telehealth therapist. Youth A recalled having a New Oakland
telehealth appointment in 05/2025 or 06/2025 for self-harming
thoughts that led directly to an evaluation at Mott Children’s
Hospital and then to her admission to Cedar Creek Hospital.
Youth A states she meets with her telehealth therapist once or
twice a week and monthly with her telehealth nurse practitioner.
Youth A did not bring up a sweatshirt incident and was not asked
to prevent the trigger of negative thoughts.
Case Manager was interviewed on 08/25/2025 by phone. Case
Manager stated she recalled writing the 05/16/2025 incident report
when Youth A’s school social worker called about Youth A being
triggered by another student. (See Documentation Reviewed for
2

incident report summary.) Case Manager stated she spoke with
Youth A when she returned from school and Youth A stated she
did not have thoughts of self-harm but safety planned with the
Clinical Coordinator. Case Manager stated she is unaware of
Youth A self-harming with the use of a sweatshirt at school.
Clinical Coordinator was interviewed on 07/30/2025 at Girlstown
and on 08/25/2025 by phone. Clinical Coordinator stated she
recalled writing the 05/16/2025 and 05/28/2025 incident reports
about safety planning with Youth A. (See Documentation
Reviewed for incident report summary.) Clinical Coordinator
stated she was unaware of Youth A self-harming with the use of a
sweatshirt at school. Clinical Coordinator stated it was determined
Youth A was not appropriate for day treatment during her phone
evaluation with New Oakland on 06/06/2025. Clinical Coordinator
stated Youth A was directly sent to University of Michigan Hospital
for an evaluation and transferred to Cedar Creek Hospital for
admission. Clinical Coordinator stated when a youth has suicide
ideation, she is placed on a safety plan or evaluated through a
telehealth appointment, New Oakland evaluation or crisis hotline.
Program Manager was interviewed on 07/30/2025 at Girlstown.
Program Manager stated Youth A was admitted to Cedar Creek
Hospital after her assessment with New Oakland determined she
was not appropriate for day treatment. Program Manager stated
Youth A was at Cedar Creek from 06/07/2025 to 06/18/2025.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on
08/04/2025 when she returned the phone call from 07/24/2025.
FCW stated there were no witnesses to Youth A tying a sweatshirt
around her neck at school in 06/2025. FCW stated she was
present during Youth A’s 06/2025 New Oakland phone evaluation
when it was agreed to take Youth A to the hospital for an in-
person evaluation. FCW stated Youth A was transferred and
admitted to Cedar Creek due to her suicidal ideation on
06/07/2025.
Documentation Reviewed
Youth A’s 05/2025 self-harm documents.
• 05/16/2025 incident report written by Case Manager stated
she spoke with the school social worker. It states a student
told Youth A to “kill herself” the day before and this caused
Youth A to scratch herself with her fingernail in her
bedroom last night. School social worker stated Youth A did
not have additional plans to self-harm. Case Manager
3

contacted Clinical Coordinator. Youth A was receptive to
safety planning.
• 05/16/2025 Youth A’s safety plan was completed with
Clinical Coordinator. Youth A identified warning signs,
coping strategies, and people she could talk with.
• 05/28/2025 incident report written by Clinical Coordinator
stated Youth A expressed self-harming thoughts. Clinical
Coordinator stated Youth A created a safety plan and staff
were made aware.
• 05/28/2025 Youth A’s safety plan was completed with
Clinical Coordinator. Youth A identified warning signs,
coping strategies, and people she could talk with.
Youth A’s 06/2025 self-harm documents.
• 06/06/2025 incident report written by Clinical Coordinator
states New Oakland and Youth A’s Foster Care Worker
recommended Youth A be evaluated at the hospital due to
suicidal ideations. It states Youth A was transported to
University of Michigan Hospital.
• Youth A was admitted to Cedar Creek Hospital from
06/07/2025 to 06/18/2025.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance in providing for Youth A’s
safety by developing safety plans, scheduling telehealth
appointments, in person psychiatric evaluation, and inpatient
psychiatric care.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (b) Denial of any essential program service as
punishment. These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(iv) Shelter, clothing, medical care, or essential personal needs,
including culturally specific items.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth felt bullied by staff and ran away from the facility for 36
hours. Youth was found on 07/02/2025 and brought back to the
facility. Once back, staff found a phone that youth had and was
texting someone about having two vape pens that youth had given
to someone else while AWOL. Up until 07/17/2025, youth has
been questioned about the vapes by staff. The staff took
4

everything out of youth’s room and locked it up leaving only a
mattress, pillow, and comforter.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was interviewed on 07/24/2025 by phone.
Complainant did not have additional information.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/24/2025 at Girlstown. Youth A
stated she called a friend when she truanted on 07/01/2025 and
her friend and her friend’s mother picked her up. Youth A stated
her friend’s mother drove her to the police station and Supervisor
picked her up and brought her back to Girlstown. Youth A stated
she gave Supervisor the password to her cell phone and
Supervisor read text messages about Youth A having vape pens.
Youth A stated the text messages did not show that she gave her
friend two vape pens. Youth A stated she was searched and the
vape pens were not found. Youth A stated she was not grounded
for the vape pens but closely monitored because she truanted.
Youth A stated she had her personal belongings in her bedroom.
(Please see 2025SIC000884. CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention
standards and prohibitions was cited because staff made
inappropriate comments to Youth A.)
Youth B was interviewed on 07/24/2025 at Girlstown. Youth B
stated she did not have a vape pen but another youth, who she
would not disclose, gave her a vape pen to turn in to get off of
being grounded. Youth B stated she took the vape pen and placed
it by the bathroom sink at the courthouse during a youth program.
Youth B stated the vape pen was found and she was ungrounded.
Youth B stated being grounded at Girlstown means remaining in
your bedroom with your personal belongings during free time and
meals. Youth B stated the bedroom door is open and a staff is
positioned in the hallway supervising the grounded youth.
Supervisor was interviewed on 07/30/2025 at Girlstown.
Supervisor stated Youth A truanted on 06/30/2025 and brought
back two vape pens on 07/01/2025, which was known through the
review of text messages from Youth A’s cell phone. Supervisor
stated during a youth courthouse program, a vape pen was found
in the bathroom, but no youth claimed knowledge or ownership of
the vape pen.
Program Manager was interviewed on 07/30/2025 at Girlstown.
Program Manager stated a grounding at Girlstown means a youth
remains in their bedroom with their personal belongings with the
5

door open. Program Manager stated a grounding is supervised by
staff and lasts up to 48 hours.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on
08/04/2025 when she returned the phone call from 07/24/2025.
FCW stated she visited Youth A at Girlstown on 07/21/2025 and
Youth A had personal items in her bedroom.
Documentation Reviewed
06/30/2025 Van Buren Township law enforcement was notified of
Youth A’s truancy at 8:00 PM.
07/01/2025 incident report written by Supervisor states Supervisor
transported Youth A back to Girlstown from Van Buren Police
station.
07/02/2025 incident report written by Supervisor states a cell
phone found in Youth A’s bag was charged and searched. The
cell phone showed it belonged to the mother of Youth A’s friend.
Text messages from the cell phone were reviewed. Text
messages disclosed the cell phone was obtained from a
community friend. Text messages were about looking for a ride,
staying in a hotel lobby, and using a vape pen.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with providing Youth A’s
clothing and essential personal needs. Youth A denied being
grounded without her personal belongings in her bedroom. Youth
B stated she was grounded and had her personal belongings in
her bedroom.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c)Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 07/14/2025, the residents were quarantined to their rooms due
to exposure to Covid. Youth has none of the coping activities to
work on while quarantined since everything is locked up. Youth
has to stay in their room with nothing to do. The supervisor was
6

made aware of the concerns and stated they would speak to the
team about it. It is still unknown if youth received their things back.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant was interviewed on 07/24/2025 by phone.
Complainant did not have additional information.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/24/2025 at Girlstown. Youth A
stated youths were quarantined 0n 07/15/2025 to 07/17/2025 due
to Covid exposure. Youth A stated she had a book that she did not
want to read and a word search book that she was not interested
in when she was quarantined in her bedroom. Youth A stated her
clothing and bedding remained in her bedroom. Youth A stated
the quarantine ended when the youths tested negative for Covid
on 07/17/2025.
Youth B was interviewed on 07/24/2025 at Girlstown. Youth B
stated Girlstown youths stayed in their bedrooms with their
belongings when recently quarantined for three days because a
staff had Covid. Youth B stated this occurred about a week ago
and did not have concerns with the quarantine.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 08/19/2025 by phone. Staff 1 stated
youths were quarantined due to Covid exposure in 07/2025. Staff
1 stated youths had coloring materials, books, and DVD players in
their bedrooms to keep occupied until the quarantine was lifted.
Clinical Coordinator was interviewed on 08/25/2025 by phone.
Clinical Coordinator stated she recalled writing the 07/15/2025
incident report stating the youths were quarantined due to Covid
exposure. (See Documentation Reviewed for incident report
summary.) Clinical Coordinator stated there were no issues with
the quarantine.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on
08/04/2025 when she returned the phone call from 07/24/2025.
FCW stated she visited Youth A at Girlstown on 07/17/2025 during
the Covid quarantine. FCW stated she observed Youth A with her
coping mechanisms of coloring books and coloring materials and
books in her bedroom.
Documentation
07/18/2025 incident report written by Clinical Coordinator states
youths were quarantined from 07/15/2025 to 07/18/2025 when a
staff relayed she tested positive for Covid after working morning
shift on 07/15/2025. Youths were Covid tested on 07/15/2025 and
7

again on 07/18/2025. All youths tested negative and were
symptom free on both dates. The quarantine was lifted on
07/18/2025.
Girlstown’s Covid policy and procedure was reviewed. It states
youths are quarantined when exposed to Covid even without
symptoms.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance for following their policy and
procedure for the care of the youths when exposed to Covid. The
youths had their personal belongings in their bedrooms during the
quarantine.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Additional Finding
Type
Investigation Interviews
Youth A was interviewed on 07/24/2024 at Girlstown. Youth A
stated she has not been given her evening medication as
prescribed. Youth A denied refusing her medications.
Program Manager was interviewed on 07/24/2025 at Girlstown.
Program Manager stated Clinical Coordinator is responsible for
reviewing a youth’s Medication Administration Record (MAR) for
compliance.
Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed on
08/04/2025 when she returned the phone call from 07/24/2025.
FCW stated Youth A’s medications were changed during her stay
at Cedar Creek, which seemed to increase agitation in Youth A.
Documentation
Youth A’s 07/2025 MAR was reviewed on 07/24/2025. Youth A’s
MAR had blank spots without supporting documentation.
• Latuda 1 pill, 40 mg at 6 PM had blank spots on the
following dates 07/01/2025, 07/03/2025, 07/04/2025,
07/18/2025, 07/19/2025, 07/21/2025, 07/22/2025, and
07/23/2025.
8

• Lithium 1 pill, 300 mg at 6 PM had blank spots on the
following dates 07/03/2025, 07/04/2025, 07/18/2025,
07/19/2025, 07/21/2025, 07/22/2025, and 07/23/2025.
There is no documentation on the MAR or elsewhere indicating
Youth A’s pill count and MAR were checked to verify medication
was dispensed as prescribed in 07/2025.
A pill count was requested due to the blank spots on Youth A’s
MAR and Clinical Coordinator facilitated the pill count on
07/24/2025. Youth A had two bottles of Latuda. Bottle 1 was filled
on 06/18/2025 with 30 pills with 3 pills remaining. Bottle 2 was
filled on 07/16/2025 with 30 pills and unopened with the seal
intact. Youth A had two bottles of Lithium. Bottle 1 was filled on
06/18/2025 with 30 pills with 1 pill remaining. Bottle 2 was filled on
07/16/2025 with 30 pills with 29 pills remaining.
Girlstown’s Medication Procedure and Administration Guidelines
policy and procedure was reviewed. It states “Staff is to place their
initials by the correct time and date of the medication log” when
dispensing medication. Policy and procedure does not address
blank spots on the MAR. Policy and procedure states “Staff will be
responsible for counting the medications, in order to properly
ensure that there is a lower probability of medications coming up
missing.”
07/01/2025 incident report written by Supervisor states Youth A
returned from truancy and took her medication before going to
bed.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance in dispensing Youth A’s
Latuda and Lithium as prescribed based on the remaining Latuda
and Lithium pills in the pill bottles and the blank spots on Youth
A’s 07/2025 MAR.
CONSULTATION
It is recommended to utilize a key for the MAR when medication is
not dispensed as prescribed (e.g. capital letter R for refusal, circle
for out of medication, T for truant) in addition to an incident report.
It is recommended for Girlstown’s Medication Procedure and
Administration Guidelines policy and procedure to identify the
person(s) that are responsible for verifying medication is
dispensed as prescribed and how verification is done. The
frequency of verification and how the verification is documented
should be included in the policy and procedure.
9

It is recommended when there are multiple pill bottles of the same
prescription that one pill bottle is completed before opening
another pill bottle.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
